Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Ariel Atkinson of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at the Advanced Water Management Centre at the University of Queensland in Brisbane, Australia. The project title is "The Effect of Organic Matter on the Fate of Disinfection By-Products during the Production of High Quality Recycled Water." The host scientist is Dr. Maria José Farré.

Water scarcity and compromised source water quality is a major issue facing many areas of the US and around the world; the need for alternative water sources continues to grow. Membranes can be used to address this problem; specifically to treat wastewater or compromised water sources in conjunction with other treatment processes to produce high quality potable water. Disinfection by-products (DBPs), which are potentially harmful to human health, are formed during water disinfection. How they can be prevented from ending up in finished water during high quality recycled water production is important for the protection of public health. This study specifically investigates the role organic matter plays on the fate of DBPs in membrane treatment. This project will add to the fundamental understanding and practical issues of membrane treatment, disinfection-by product fate, water recycling, and the implementation of this new technology. The production of high quality water from wastewater can be a major sustainable alternative source for drinking water, and the inevitable move toward potable water reuse makes the thorough investigation of water recycling even more vital at this time.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAPSI fellowship was carried out at the Advanced Water Management Centre at the University of Queensland in collaboration with Dr. Maria José Farré. The research broadly focuses on the use of membranes for the production of high quality water from wastewater effluent, as a potential alternative drinking water source. Specifically the project addresses how variable membrane surface fouling affects the fate of regulated and emerging disinfection by-products (DBPs) in membrane treatment. Only a few studies have been published on the rejection of regulated and emerging DBPs by membrane treatment and the effect of operational conditions.

In the laboratory several experiments were carried out where a secondary wastewater effluent matrix was altered, membrane treatment simulations were performed, and the effect of the alterations on the rejection of DBPs by the nanofiltration membranes was evaluated. In order to interpret the results, analysis and characterization of the water matrices, membrane surfaces, and DBPs were performed.  

Though the results and findings of this project are still being evaluated, a manuscript for publication in an academic journal is currently being prepared. It is also expected that the findings will be disseminated at a national conference poster/presentation.

The conclusions of this project in conjunction with other research have broad impacts. The results can be utilized by policy and decision makers to better understand the potential use of this technology to provide a safe alternative drinking water source and better understand its potential impact on public health. Existing and future water treatment plants utilizing membrane technology and the membrane industry itself can use the outcomes of this research project to better design membranes and treatment trains to minimize the levels of DBPs in the finished water.

This project provided an opportunity for the exchange of ideas and information that would not be available otherwise, as well as the development of lasting professional relationships that could potentially lead to multiple international collaborations in the future. The PI was trained on new analytical protocols, tools, and instruments; as well as on the use of additional water treatment equipment. The PI was also able to tour and communicate directly with an Advanced Water Treatment Facility and it’s staff; which are not otherwise easily available to the PI in the US. At the facility, the PI was able to learn about the equipment in use and operational details. Overall, the project allowed for professional development of the PI and the formation of expertise and contacts that will advance the PIs research and the field in general.
